**Short answer.** Yes—there are real, technical links between the **principle of least action (PLA)** and **entropy maximization**. The tightest connections appear when you (i) look at **probability measures over trajectories** (MaxEnt’s dynamical extension “**maximum caliber**”), (ii) work in **stochastic or coarse‑grained dynamics**, where the **most probable** path minimizes an **action‑like rate functional**, and (iii) rotate to **Euclidean (imaginary) time**, where the **action becomes a thermodynamic free‑energy** and entropies enter explicitly. But PLA and MaxEnt are *not the same principle*: PLA governs deterministic, often time‑reversible dynamics via stationary phase, whereas MaxEnt/MaxCal are inference principles for probability laws given constraints. Below I map the firm bridges, the limits, and a forward‑looking synthesis.  

---

## 1) Where the link is rigorous

### A. Path measures: MaxCal → action weights → Euler–Lagrange
Jaynes’s **maximum caliber** (MaxCal) maximizes the **path entropy** over all trajectories subject to dynamical constraints. The solution is a **Gibbs measure on paths**,  
\[
\rho[\gamma]\;\propto\;\exp\!\Big(-\sum_k\int\lambda_k(t)\,A_k(\gamma,t)\,dt\Big).
\]  
When the constrained path functionals \(A_k\) collectively define a Lagrangian \(L(x,\dot x,t)\), this takes the form \(\rho[\gamma]\propto e^{-\int L\,dt}\). The **mode** (or MAP path) then **extremizes** \(\int L\,dt\) and obeys the **Euler–Lagrange equations**, recovering PLA as the typical path in the small‑noise/MAP limit. This program—and many concrete derivations—are laid out in reviews and case studies of MaxCal. citeturn0search1turn0search6turn0search11

### B. Stochastic dynamics: Onsager–Machlup / Large deviations
For diffusions \(dX_t=b(X_t,t)\,dt+\sqrt{2D}\,dW_t\), the probability of an entire trajectory concentrates as  
\[
\mathbb P(\gamma)\;\asymp\;\exp\!\Big(-\frac{1}{4D}\int_0^T\!\|\dot x-b(x,t)\|^2\,dt\Big),
\]  
the **Onsager–Machlup** functional. The **most probable path** minimizes this **action functional**; more generally, Freidlin–Wentzell **large‑deviation theory** shows that rare event probabilities are governed by a rate function often interpretable as an action. This is a direct stochastic counterpart of “least action,” and it ties the weight of a path to an **entropic cost** (a relative entropy; see next item). citeturn0search2turn0search17turn9search0

### C. Relative entropy as “action” on path space
In modern nonequilibrium statistical mechanics, **entropy production** is a **Kullback–Leibler (KL)** divergence between a **forward** and a **time‑reversed** **path measure**. Large‑deviation rate functions and Onsager–Machlup functionals can be written as—or bounded by—such KLs. Thus, the “action” governing path weights is literally an **information‑theoretic distance**. This unifies **PLA‑like minimization** with **entropy/KL extremization**. citeturn3search10turn3search1turn3search3

### D. Schrödinger bridges & entropic optimal transport (control‑as‑inference)
The **Schrödinger bridge** (SB) seeks the **most likely** stochastic flow that transports an initial distribution to a final one, **minimizing KL** to a reference (e.g., Wiener) prior. SB is **entropy‑regularized optimal transport**; in small noise it converges to **OT geodesics** (which minimize kinetic action). SB thereby exhibits an explicit **MaxEnt/MaxCal ⇒ action‑minimization** equivalence on path space and has become central in generative modeling and stochastic control. citeturn12search3turn0search18turn12search2

### E. Euclidean time: action ↔ thermodynamic free energy
In **imaginary (Euclidean) time**, quantum path integrals weigh paths by \(\exp[-S_E/\hbar]\), directly analogous to Boltzmann weights; the **Euclidean action \(S_E\)** functions like a \(\beta F\). In gravity, the **on‑shell Euclidean action** (with proper Gibbons–Hawking boundary terms) computes partition functions and **black‑hole entropies/free energies**—a mature, quantitative bridge linking action to thermodynamics/entropy. citeturn0search4turn5search1turn4search17

> **Bottom line:** In each of these settings, an **extremum of an action functional** is simultaneously an **extremum of an (information‑theoretic) entropy functional** over paths, after choosing the right prior and constraints.

---

## 2) Where the link is nuanced or limited

- **PLA vs MaxEnt differ in status.** PLA is a **dynamical law** (from Hamilton’s principle) whose real‑time path integral counterpart uses **oscillatory phases**; the classical limit emerges by **stationary phase**, not by maximizing a probability. The **probabilistic/entropic** reading requires **stochasticity** or **Euclidean rotation** (or both). citeturn0search9turn0search4

- **“Least” vs “stationary.”** PLA is a **stationary** action principle; minima are not guaranteed. Omitting this subtlety blurs distinctions with “maximization” views. (Standard expositions emphasize “stationary.”) citeturn7search7

- **MEP/MINEP caveats.** The **minimum entropy production** principle (Prigogine) is valid only **near equilibrium** (linear regime); general claims beyond that fail. Conversely, **maximum entropy production (MEP)** has domains of usefulness but remains far from a universal law. Treat both as **heuristics or inference devices**, not bedrock principles. citeturn6search6turn6search14turn6search1

- **“Free‑energy principle” analogies.** Bayesian/variational “free‑energy” frameworks in neuroscience and complex systems often draw analogies to PLA; the connections are suggestive but under active debate on scope and exactness. citeturn1search3turn1search18

---

## 3) How the pieces fit together (a compact mathematical skeleton)

Let \(P\) be a **prior path measure** (e.g., Wiener measure with diffusion \(D\)). Choose **constraints** on path functionals \(A_k[\gamma]\) (energetics, currents, boundary marginals). The **MaxCal/SB** problem is  
\[
\textbf{maximize}\quad \mathcal S(\rho)= -\mathrm{KL}(\rho\Vert P)\quad
\textbf{subject to}\ \ \mathbb E_\rho[A_k]=a_k.
\]  
The solution has density \(d\rho^\star/dP \propto e^{-\sum_k \lambda_k A_k[\gamma]}\). If \(\sum_k \lambda_k A_k = \int_0^T L(x,\dot x,t)\,dt\), then the **MAP** path \(\gamma^\star\) **extremizes** \(\int L\,dt\) and satisfies **Euler–Lagrange**. With a diffusion prior, the **rate functional** becomes an **Onsager–Machlup/Freidlin–Wentzell action**, whose minimizers are **most probable trajectories**. In **Euclidean time**, the same weight is a **Boltzmann factor**, hence a **free‑energy/entropy** extremum. citeturn0search6turn0search2turn9search6turn12search3

---

## 4) “Latest thinking” snapshots (2024–2025)

- **From meso to macro:** New **RMP (2025)** reviews connect **stochastic thermodynamics** for Markov jump/diffusion processes to deterministic macroscopic laws, consolidating KL/entropy‑production and large‑deviation structure as the bridge between micro paths and macro dynamics. citeturn0search12

- **Bridging large deviations and ST directly:** Recent work (2025) forges explicit links between **Freidlin–Wentzell** rate functionals and **entropy production**, sharpening the action–entropy correspondence in nonequilibrium settings. citeturn11search0

- **Schrödinger bridges in practice:** Ongoing advances in SB theory/algorithms (2024–2025) expand its role across physics and ML, reinforcing the **KL‑regularized action minimization** picture of dynamics. citeturn12search2turn12search7

- **Gravitation:** Fresh analyses of **Euclidean gravitational actions** and black‑hole phase structure continue to equate **on‑shell action** with **thermodynamic potentials/entropies**, keeping the action–entropy tie operational in high‑energy theory. citeturn4search5turn4search13

---

## 5) My assessment (speculative, but grounded)

**A unified “inference–dynamics” variational principle.** A clean way to view PLA and MaxEnt as two faces of the same coin is to formulate physics on **path space** with a **prior** \(P\) encoding symmetries/noise and then **extremize**
\[
\mathcal{J}(\rho)=\mathrm{KL}(\rho\Vert P)\;+\;\beta\,\mathbb E_\rho\!\Big[\int_0^T V(x_t,t)\,dt\Big]
\quad \text{under boundary/data constraints.}
\]
- In the **small‑noise** (or **MAP**) limit: \(\rho\) concentrates, and \(\mathcal{J}\) reduces to an **effective action** \(S_{\rm eff}=\int (K-V)\,dt\); **PLA** (Euler–Lagrange) emerges.  
- At **finite noise/coarse‑graining**: the objective is a **relative‑entropy‑regularized control problem** (SB/control‑as‑inference), and minimizers are **most‑probable flows** with **entropy production** equal to a **KL**.  
- Under **Euclidean rotation**: \(S_{\rm eff}\) **is** \(\beta F\); extremizing \(\mathcal{J}\) becomes ordinary **free‑energy minimization**.  

This perspective is already explicit in MaxCal, large deviations, SB, and stochastic control literatures; the unification is to **treat mechanics as constrained inference on paths**, with **PLA as the zero‑noise limit** and **entropy production as the information‑theoretic price of irreversibility**. What is still missing (a worthwhile research program):

1) **Noether‑style theorems for inference:** make precise how **symmetries of the prior/constraints** imply **conserved currents** for the **posterior path law** (some steps exist, but a general theory is nascent). citeturn10search0  
2) **Dissipation and open systems:** a canonical “action” for generic nonequilibrium dynamics that **adds** friction and constraints without ad hoc terms (recent large‑deviation/HJB connections are promising). citeturn11search2  
3) **Quantum, real time:** tighten the bridge between **stationary phase (real time)** and **entropy/KL** beyond the Euclidean trick—i.e., identify when **informational extremals** control **phase interference**. (This is largely open.) citeturn0search9

---

## 6) Practical takeaways

- If you want PLA to “come from entropy,” **work on path ensembles** (MaxCal/SB), not single microstates. Then least‑action equations reappear as **most‑likely** or **MAP** paths given constraints. citeturn0search1  
- In nonequilibrium problems, treat the **action** as a **relative entropy** on path space; then **entropy production** quantifies how “costly” it is to realize a trajectory—a direct, computable connection now used widely (e.g., single‑molecule and active matter). citeturn3search7turn3search13  
- In QFT/gravity, **Euclidean methods** make the action/free‑energy/entropy equivalence **literal** and quantitatively predictive. citeturn5search1turn4search17

---

## References (selected, recent & foundational)

- **MaxCal & Variational Inference on Paths:** Pressé et al., *Rev. Mod. Phys.* 85, 1115 (2013); Ghosh et al., *J. Chem. Phys.* 148, 010901 (2018); General, *Phys. Rev. E* 98, 012110 (2018). citeturn0search1turn0search6turn0search11  
- **Stochastic Thermodynamics & Large Deviations:** Seifert, *Rep. Prog. Phys.* 75, 126001 (2012); Crooks, *Phys. Rev. E* 60, 2721 (1999); Falasco et al., *Rev. Mod. Phys.* 97, 015002 (2025). citeturn0search2turn3search10turn0search12  
- **Schrödinger Bridge / Entropic OT:** Léonard, survey (2013/2014); Di Marino & Gerolin, *J. Sci. Comput.* 85, 27 (2020); recent algorithmic advances (2025). citeturn12search3turn0search18turn12search1  
- **Euclidean Action ↔ Free Energy / Black‑Hole Thermodynamics:** Gibbons & Hawking (1977); Hawking & Page (1983); Cheng et al., *Phys. Rev. D* 111, L041503 (2025). citeturn5search1turn4search17turn4search5

---

### Bottom line for a researcher
Treat **PLA** and **entropy maximization** as **two presentations of one variational structure on path space**: in **deterministic** regimes, you see **stationary action**; in **stochastic/nonequilibrium** regimes, you see **KL/entropy**. The “right” formulation depends on which side of that spectrum you’re on. The current frontier is making these correspondences **structural** (symmetries, conservation, geometry) rather than case‑by‑case—an area where your mathematical toolkit (variational calculus, large deviations, information geometry) is directly applicable. citeturn11search2
